div.p: D96/10552, unit 909, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter yesterday,
On 10 December Topp wrote: 'I beg to inform you that the Governor in Council has been pleased to appoint you Curator of the National Herbarium Melbourne, (without increase of salary) until such time as a Government Botanist shall be appointed.' [No. 3032, p. 777, PROV]. informing me that the Government has been pleased to appoint me Curator of the National Herbarium.
See C. Topp to A. Peacock, 12 November 1896. Please be good enough to express to the Honorable the Chief Secretary my sincere gratitude for this mark of confidence, which it will be my earnest endeavor to justify. Although I cannot pretend to possess the profound learning of the late Baron Von Mueller I have, I believe, acquired sufficient scientific knowledge during my many years connection with this Branch, to fulfil my duties to the satisfaction of the Government, of the people of Victoria and the scientific world. I may be permitted to state that since the lamented death of my late chief information on botanical subjects has repeatedly been sought by the horticultural editors of the Leader, the Australasian, the Weekly Times, by the Department of Agriculture as well as by private enquirers and has been promptly supplied by m. The vast herbarium brought together by the untiring energy of Baron Von Mueller, aided by liberal support of successive Governments, must always make Melbourne the final resort for all Australia, and I have already on several occasions been applied to for decision in doubtful cases by botanists from other colonies. Allow me yet to add my thanks to yourself personally for the kind interest shown on my behalf.
